headline: Big Tech earnings to test AI rally as resurgent Alphabet takes lead
summary: Microsoft and Meta will kick off Big Tech earnings this week under pressure to prove that their costly bets on artificial intelligence can power another year of strong growth as a resurgent Alphabet takes the lead in the high-stakes ​race.  The companies, along with Amazon, are expected to lift their AI spending by 30% to more than $500 billion this year, an unprecedented outlay ‌that will sharpen investor scrutiny.  Doubts have deepened whether Microsoft has squandered a first-mover advantage in AI it secured through its OpenAI investment.

content.title: Big Tech earnings to test AI rally as resurgent Alphabet takes lead

The companies, along with Amazon, are expected to lift their AI spending by 30% to more than $500 billion this year, an unprecedented outlay ‌that will sharpen investor scrutiny.  Doubts have deepened whether Microsoft has squandered a first-mover advantage in AI it secured through its OpenAI investment.

headline: Tesla’s Price Target Is Rising Even as Its Profit Outlook Tanks
summary: “Tesla is truly unique in capital markets,” said Nicholas Colas, co-founder at DataTrek Research.  Over the past 12 months, the average forecast for Tesla’s 2026 net income has tumbled 56% from $14.1 billion to $6.1 billion.  The stock is up 7% in that time after closing Tuesday at $435.20, well above Wall Street’s expectations for a year from now.

content.title: Tesla’s Price Target Is Rising Even as Its Profit Outlook Tanks
content.summary: “Tesla is truly unique in capital markets,” said Nicholas Colas, co-founder at DataTrek Research.  Over the past 12 months, the average forecast for Tesla’s 2026 net income has tumbled 56% from $14.1 billion to $6.1 billion.  The stock is up 7% in that time after closing Tuesday at $435.20, well above Wall Street’s expectations for a year from now.

headline: Meta signs deal to pay Corning up to $6 billion for fiber-optic cables, CNBC reports
summary: Facebook parent Meta Platforms has signed a deal to pay Gorilla Glass maker Corning up to $6 ​billion through 2030 for fiber-optic cables in its AI ‌data centers, CNBC reported on Tuesday.  The company expects AI hyperscalers, including Meta, Amazon, ‌Alphabet's Google and Microsoft, to be its biggest customers next year, the report said, citing an interview with Corning CEO Wendell Weeks.  Corning's optical connectivity products are among key components required to support the ⁠massive computing and data ‌transmission demands at data centers.

content.title: Meta signs deal to pay Corning up to $6 billion for fiber-optic cables, CNBC reports
content.summary: Facebook parent Meta Platforms has signed a deal to pay Gorilla Glass maker Corning up to $6 ​billion through 2030 for fiber-optic cables in its AI ‌data centers, CNBC reported on Tuesday.  The company expects AI hyperscalers, including Meta, Amazon, ‌Alphabet's Google and Microsoft, to be its biggest customers next year, the report said, citing an interview with Corning CEO Wendell Weeks.  Corning's optical connectivity products are among key components required to support the ⁠massive computing and data ‌transmission demands at data centers.

headline: Is Comcast (CMCSA) Quietly Redrawing Its Core Business Map With the Versant Spin-Off?
summary: In recent weeks, Comcast has opened new Xfinity Stores in South DeKalb, Georgia and Chehalis, Washington, expanded its Amazon Luna gaming rollout, completed the spin-off of Versant Media Group, and reported continued use of AI across its advertising operations. Together with customer retention efforts like the Xfinity Membership loyalty program and a pause on near-term internet price hikes, these moves highlight Comcast’s focus on recalibrating its connectivity, media, and retail footprint...

headline: Microsoft’s New AI Chip Can’t Keep Nvidia Stock Down
summary: Nvidia  stock was rising early Tuesday even as  Microsoft  revealed the use of its own artificial-intelligence chip.  The focus for the week is on earnings from Microsoft and  Meta Platforms  both big customers of Nvidia.  “Maia 200 is…the most efficient inference system Microsoft has ever deployed, with 30% better performance per dollar than the latest generation hardware in our fleet today,” said Scott Guthrie, executive vice president of the Microsoft Cloud and AI Group, in a statement.

headline: Big Tech earnings to test AI rally as resurgent Alphabet takes lead
summary:
STORY: Microsoft and Meta will kick off Big Tech earnings this week under pressure to prove their costly bets on AI can power another year of strong growth.

That's as a resurgent Alphabet takes the lead in the high-stakes race.

The companies, along with Amazon, are expected to lift their AI spending this year by 30% to more than $500 billion.

It's an unprecedented outlay that will sharpen investor scrutiny.

Some have expressed doubts over whether Microsoft squandered a first-mover advantage in AI it secured through its OpenAI investment.

Meta too is under pressure to show payoffs from its expensive push into superintelligence.

Both stocks declined more than 6% in the last three months of 2025.

While Amazon saw a small 5% gain after its November deal with OpenAI signaled that the largest cloud-computing provider in the U.S. was no longer behind on AI.

Alphabet shares though surged about 29% in that period.

It followed a strong reception of Google's latest Gemini 3 model.

The company also recently struck a deal to power Apple's revamped Siri.

LSEG data showed that in the October-December quarter, Google Cloud revenue growth likely quickened to 35% from 33.5% in the previous three months.

But doubts linger about the real-world benefits for the businesses adopting the technology.

And feeding into bubble fears that hounded the technology industry for much of last year.

content.title: Big Tech earnings to test AI rally as resurgent Alphabet takes lead
content.summary:
STORY: Microsoft and Meta will kick off Big Tech earnings this week under pressure to prove their costly bets on AI can power another year of strong growth.

That's as a resurgent Alphabet takes the lead in the high-stakes race.

The companies, along with Amazon, are expected to lift their AI spending this year by 30% to more than $500 billion.

It's an unprecedented outlay that will sharpen investor scrutiny.

Some have expressed doubts over whether Microsoft squandered a first-mover advantage in AI it secured through its OpenAI investment.

Meta too is under pressure to show payoffs from its expensive push into superintelligence.

Both stocks declined more than 6% in the last three months of 2025.

While Amazon saw a small 5% gain after its November deal with OpenAI signaled that the largest cloud-computing provider in the U.S. was no longer behind on AI.

Alphabet shares though surged about 29% in that period.

It followed a strong reception of Google's latest Gemini 3 model.

The company also recently struck a deal to power Apple's revamped Siri.

LSEG data showed that in the October-December quarter, Google Cloud revenue growth likely quickened to 35% from 33.5% in the previous three months.

But doubts linger about the real-world benefits for the businesses adopting the technology.

And feeding into bubble fears that hounded the technology industry for much of last year.

headline: Billionaire Charlie Munger Said 'Damn Right' I Am Rich Owning 3 Stocks—Because 'Hell, One Will Suffice' If You're Not A 'Know-Nothing Investor'
summary: Charlie Munger didn't need 50 stocks, a team of analysts, or a color-coded pie chart to feel rich. He needed three picks—and maybe not even that many. At the 2017 Daily Journal annual meeting, Munger laid it out with signature bluntness: "The Mungers have three stocks. We have a block of Berkshire, we have a block of Costco, we have a block of Li Lu's Fund, and the rest is dribs and drabs." Then he posed the question himself: "So am I comfortable? Am I securely rich? You're damn right I am." Whi

headline: Amazon Is Closing Its Fresh Grocery, Go Convenience Stores
summary: Amazon Fresh and Amazon Go stores will close, the company said in a blog post on Tuesday, with some locations converted into Whole Foods Market stores.  “While we’ve seen encouraging signals in our Amazon-branded physical grocery stores, we haven’t yet created a truly distinctive customer experience with the right economic model needed for large-scale expansion,” Amazon said.  Since the surprise opening of a physical bookstore in 2015, Amazon has tried and failed to establish a foothold under its own brand in categories from groceries to fashion, often with technology flourishes like digital price tags or novel checkout methods.

content.title: Amazon Is Closing Its Fresh Grocery, Go Convenience Stores
content.summary: Amazon Fresh and Amazon Go stores will close, the company said in a blog post on Tuesday, with some locations converted into Whole Foods Market stores.  “While we’ve seen encouraging signals in our Amazon-branded physical grocery stores, we haven’t yet created a truly distinctive customer experience with the right economic model needed for large-scale expansion,” Amazon said.  Since the surprise opening of a physical bookstore in 2015, Amazon has tried and failed to establish a foothold under its own brand in categories from groceries to fashion, often with technology flourishes like digital price tags or novel checkout methods.

headline: Amazon to Shut Down All Amazon Go and Amazon Fresh Stores
summary: BUSINESS   Amazon is closing all of its Amazon Go and Amazon Fresh physical stores in a shift to focus on its online same-day delivery service and new big-box retail stores.  The e-commerce giant said Tuesday that some of its shuttered Amazon-branded brick-and-mortar stores would be converted into Whole Foods Market locations.

content.title: Amazon to Shut Down All Amazon Go and Amazon Fresh Stores
content.summary: BUSINESS   Amazon is closing all of its Amazon Go and Amazon Fresh physical stores in a shift to focus on its online same-day delivery service and new big-box retail stores.  The e-commerce giant said Tuesday that some of its shuttered Amazon-branded brick-and-mortar stores would be converted into Whole Foods Market locations.

headline: Pinterest will lay off 15% of its workforce as the platform pivots resources to AI
summary: Pinterest plans to lay off under 15% of its workforce, as part of broader restructuring that arrives as the image-sharing platform pivots more of its money to artificial intelligence.  In a Tuesday securities filing, San Francisco-based Pinterest said it was making these cuts to support “transformation initiatives” — which include reallocating the company's resources to AI-focused roles and prioritizing AI-powered products.  Beyond the coming layoffs, Pinterest said it will reduce office space.

content.title: Pinterest will lay off 15% of its workforce as the platform pivots resources to AI
content.summary: Pinterest plans to lay off under 15% of its workforce, as part of broader restructuring that arrives as the image-sharing platform pivots more of its money to artificial intelligence.  In a Tuesday securities filing, San Francisco-based Pinterest said it was making these cuts to support “transformation initiatives” — which include reallocating the company's resources to AI-focused roles and prioritizing AI-powered products.  Beyond the coming layoffs, Pinterest said it will reduce office space.

headline: Amazon to close Amazon Go and Amazon Fresh to concentrate on Whole Foods and grocery delivery
summary: Amazon said it's closing all of its Amazon Go and Amazon Fresh locations, as the online behemoth focuses on its grocery delivery, Whole Foods Market and a new “supersized” store concept.  The Seattle-based online retailer said Tuesday in a blog post that it plans to convert some of those soon-to-be shuttered locations into Whole Foods Market stores.  The company operates 57 Amazon Fresh stores and 15 Amazon Go stores.

content.title: Amazon to close Amazon Go and Amazon Fresh to concentrate on Whole Foods and grocery delivery
content.summary: Amazon said it's closing all of its Amazon Go and Amazon Fresh locations, as the online behemoth focuses on its grocery delivery, Whole Foods Market and a new “supersized” store concept.  The Seattle-based online retailer said Tuesday in a blog post that it plans to convert some of those soon-to-be shuttered locations into Whole Foods Market stores.  The company operates 57 Amazon Fresh stores and 15 Amazon Go stores.

headline: UPS looks to cut up to 30,000 jobs this year
summary: UPS is planning to cut up to 30,000 operational jobs this year as the package delivery company continues with its turnaround efforts and reducing the number of Amazon shipments that it handles.  Chief Financial Officer Brian Dykes said during the company's conference call on Tuesday that the job cuts will be made through a voluntary buyout offer for full-time drivers and through attrition.  UPS said in a regulatory filing in October that it had cut about 34,000 operational positions and closed daily operations at 93 leased and owned buildings during the first nine months of last year.

content.title: UPS looks to cut up to 30,000 jobs this year
content.summary: UPS is planning to cut up to 30,000 operational jobs this year as the package delivery company continues with its turnaround efforts and reducing the number of Amazon shipments that it handles.  Chief Financial Officer Brian Dykes said during the company's conference call on Tuesday that the job cuts will be made through a voluntary buyout offer for full-time drivers and through attrition.  UPS said in a regulatory filing in October that it had cut about 34,000 operational positions and closed daily operations at 93 leased and owned buildings during the first nine months of last year.

headline: Tech stocks strong but earnings may add volatility, says market expert
summary:
STORY: Rathbun said the S&P 500 reaching a record high could be "nerve-wracking" to some, but added that she remains "positive" on the index.

"A lot of people are ready for a correction and we may get that, but a lot of the companies underneath, the fundamentals are pretty strong, especially when it comes to the tech side," she said. "So I wouldn't be too worried about the S&P 500 going up." 

She adds that Amazon is one company that will be closely watched this earnings season.

"If we don't hear of something, good news with regards to AI, especially in their cloud infrastructure, I think there may be some disappointment," she said.

content.title: Tech stocks strong but earnings may add volatility, says market expert
content.summary:
STORY: Rathbun said the S&P 500 reaching a record high could be "nerve-wracking" to some, but added that she remains "positive" on the index.

"A lot of people are ready for a correction and we may get that, but a lot of the companies underneath, the fundamentals are pretty strong, especially when it comes to the tech side," she said. "So I wouldn't be too worried about the S&P 500 going up." 

She adds that Amazon is one company that will be closely watched this earnings season.

"If we don't hear of something, good news with regards to AI, especially in their cloud infrastructure, I think there may be some disappointment," she said.

headline: Are You Richer Than You Feel? Nearly 70% Of Millionaires Don't Consider Themselves Wealthy
summary: If being a millionaire used to mean yacht parties and champagne toasts, someone forgot to tell today's millionaires. Turns out, having seven figures in the bank doesn't always come with a sense of financial comfort—or even confidence. According to the 2025 Planning & Progress Study by Northwestern Mutual, only 36% of U.S. adults with at least $1 million in investable assets actually consider themselves "wealthy." That means 64%—despite their millionaire status—feel like they're still chasing fin

headline: Berkshire Hathaway Will Lose Its Biggest Mutual-Fund Fan With Danoff’s Retirement
summary: The mutual-fund industry will lose its biggest fan of  Berkshire Hathaway  with the retirement of Fidelity Contrafund manager Will Danoff at the end of 2026 after 35 years at its helm.  Danoff’s $176 billion fund probably was the single largest holder of Berkshire among actively managed mutual funds.  Contrafund’s stake in Berkshire is now worth about $10 billion, Barron’s calculates.

content.title: Berkshire Hathaway Will Lose Its Biggest Mutual-Fund Fan With Danoff’s Retirement
content.summary: The mutual-fund industry will lose its biggest fan of  Berkshire Hathaway  with the retirement of Fidelity Contrafund manager Will Danoff at the end of 2026 after 35 years at its helm.  Danoff’s $176 billion fund probably was the single largest holder of Berkshire among actively managed mutual funds.  Contrafund’s stake in Berkshire is now worth about $10 billion, Barron’s calculates.
